snippet.textDisplay:
@TheMostBleedingHeart I don't get how people say Pokemon is repetitive when it incorporates new graphical styles, gameplay mechanics, characters (humans and Pokemon), plots, and settings every game. Sure, it maintains a similar gameplay style to its predecessors, but it's no more repetitive in this fashion than most RPG games or sequels within a series. If you take any games of different generations, even ones with only a one generation difference, and compare the gameplay, there's hardly any repetition in them. I've found each generation has massive differences in the game experience, and while each game has mostly retained its appeal and resisted the "aged badly" effect, each generation has had major improvements on the previous.
...Given, Diamond and Pearl kind of sucked, but Platinum fixed all of the major issues with that and is honestly a phenomenal game.
I do really want to hear your opinion, though. What makes it too repetitive? I've always found that it maintains the core gameplay and functional environment to showcase it very well while changing the game enough to create fresh experiences and major differentiation.
...Also, in anticipation of a possible "same thing every time catch Pokemon battle gyms" argument, there are a ridiculous amount of spin-offs that are completely different from that kind of gameplay (Ranger, Conquest, Mystery Dungeon, Rumble, etc). If you're looking for a different approach to the Pokemon series, you could always try those. In my opinion, the main series is the MAIN series for a reason, and should maintain the Pokemon series-style gameplay while the spin-off games should have the change in style that some people ask for.

snippet.textDisplay: Metroid Prime, one of the best games of all time. What about this game? This game is a masterpiece, it is a major monument of gaming. This is not really a "FPS" as another, it is a great mixed with exploration and action (with a little bit platforms!) Adventure. A planet to discover, boss worthy of the name defeat, powers and objects to go back. Worked very graphics, an almost perfect gameplay, superb music, a mysterious and interesting storyline and a well balanced difficulty. I really recommend this gaming gem is a real treat. Metroid Prime: 20/20 richly deserved that reflects the greatness of this game.

snippet.textDisplay:
+reniisgod I still cannot believe how good that game is. 1994 as well.
While I personally prefer Prime, and IMO I think Prime and Super are on near equal levels of brilliance, I can definitely see why a lot of people think Super is better. I think Super has the better atmosphere and gameplay, I just love Prime's environments and especially the scan visor. One of my favourites things in any video game.
Wonder if we'll ever see another Metroid game as good as these two. Not saying the others (except for... you know what) are bad, but they aren't as strong as Super or Prime.

snippet.textDisplay: @Yayfaceman I can't speak for anyone but myself, but I thought that Other M was a horrible skid mark on Metroid's otherwise spotless track record. snippet.textDisplay:
@austinthebookworm5 I can't believe it's been over a year since my last playthrough of this game (which was my 2nd playthrough and was meant to fuel a hype train for Other M).  That being said, Prime definitely plays FAR more like a Zelda game than any shooter, which is the main reason why most of us don't consider it to be an FPS.

Fun fact: Miyamoto originally intended Ocarina of Time to be entirely in first-person, but that was rejected and obviously ended up in Metroid Prime instead.

snippet.textDisplay: @geno1082 I guess it all comes down to how few games in general the N64 had.  As someone who doesn't like the Legend of Zelda series, I can only genuinely say I liked StarFox 64, Banjo Kazooie, Mario 64, Paper Mario and a few multiplayer experiences like Mario Kart, Mario Party and Goldeneye.  And not all of those were top tier games either.
snippet.textOriginal: @geno1082 I guess it all comes down to how few games in general the N64 had.  As someone who doesn't like the Legend of Zelda series, I can only genuinely say I liked StarFox 64, Banjo Kazooie, Mario 64, Paper Mario and a few multiplayer experiences like Mario Kart, Mario Party and Goldeneye. snippet.textDisplay: @RayLedgend. What makes the Cube much better than the 64? There are some great games on the Gamecube, but none really give me that same feeling like when I play the 64. A Link to the Past and SuperMario RPG are my top two favorite games, but the 64 still reigns supreme. Whatever your opinion, it's all good.

snippet.textDisplay: @Tezcatlepocatl The way I see it is that N64 may have had some of the best games, but it had very few of them.  Not a lot of developers worked with Nintendo in the N64 days, since Sony had over a year of a head start in the market, and used discs.  The result was a few great games, and a lot of bad ones, and not a lot of in betweens.  6, maybe 7 of my top 20 games of all time were on Gamecube.  I'd be generous to fit more than 2 N64 on the list.  That's just my opinion, though =P
snippet.textOriginal: @Tezcatlepocatl The way I see it is that N64 may have had some of the best games, but it had very few of them. snippet.textDisplay:
I disagree. While there hasn't been any more real violence (or rather, the same violence) consider the timeline in stories:

First few games: kill all the Metroids and defeat Mother Brain.
Metroid Prime: stop the corruption and destruction of the last home of the Chozo by Space Pirates.
MP2: End a War between the two halves of Aether.
MP3: Fight a war with the Space Pirates, fight your allies, and prevent galatic corruption, while dealing with your own.

From exterminator to Galactic war.
